Award.AwardTitle: Activities of the Polar Research Board
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical

The Polar Research Board (PRB) is the focal point within the US National Academies for providing scientific advice on issues related to the Arctic, Antarctic, and cold regions in general. The PRB does not conduct scientific research, but instead works to synthesize existing information so it is useful to decision makers. The PRB seeks to increase understanding of the polar sciences among state and federal decision makers and others. The Board's overall mission is to help polar science have a broader impact on society, both in the United States and in the international arena. This award will provide partial support for the expenses associated with the activities and operations of the PRB over a period of three years. NOAA and NASA provide additional funds toward the PRB's operations and activities.

Technical

The PRB serves at the interface of polar science and policy, across disciplines, and across both northern and southern polar regions. The PRB's mission is to advance understanding of the polar regions, including all areas of science, engineering, human dimensions, and policy; foster application of polar science to benefit the public and decision makers; advise U.S. research programs so they are responsive to the needs of the nation; encourage interdisciplinary and cross polar perspectives; and provide a forum for independent discussion of polar issues. Activities include discussion forums, program reviews, assistance in setting priorities and identifying research opportunities, evaluation of relevant technologies, analyses of controversial and nationally important topics, and other tasks as needed. The Board does not conduct research, but helps to focus and integrate information and thus give polar research more visibility and a broader impact on society, both in the United States and internationally. The PRB also serves as the U.S. National Committee to two international polar science organizations -- the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) and the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC).

The PRB's activities bring diverse scientific perspectives together in service to national needs. The PRB strives to enhance understanding of the Arctic and Antarctic, provide independent views on U.S. research efforts, ensure that the polar science community is involved in government decision-making, and grow US leadership in international activities. The Board asks the "best and brightest" scientists to volunteer their time, and these volunteers are the intellectual force behind all the Board's work. Participants are selected with care to bring a diversity of expertise and experience; they are broad thinkers who can both react to requests for assistance and look ahead to anticipate issues. The Board is increasingly effective, conducting more visible activities, and has earned a reputation for timely and frank guidance.
In the three years of this award, the PRB expects to serve the Nation by addressing priority issues either requested by agencies or identified by the Board's members -- through informal discussions at the Board meetings, and through the development of new ad hoc study and workshop activities. The Board will also continue to facilitate U.S. participation in IASC and SCAR, and seek ways to make these organizations valuable to U.S. interests.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine are private, nonprofit institutions that provide expert advice on some of the most pressing challenges facing the nation and the world. Our work helps shape sound policies, inform public opinion, and advance the pursuit of science, engineering, and medicine. The Polar Research Board (PRB or Board) is the focal point for providing advice on issues related to the Arctic, Antarctic, and cold regions in general. Activities include (but are not limited to): discussion forums; program and document reviews; assistance in setting priorities and identifying research opportunities; evaluation of technologies and methodologies; analyses of controversial and nationally important topics; and information dissemination. The PRB serves as a unique resource to federal agencies, Congress, and others with interests in cold regions, with its coverage of both Arctic and Antarctic science, and the fact that it is both responsive to government requests and proactive in identifying issues that merit discussion.

The PRB also serves as the U.S. National Committee to two international polar science organizations—the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) and the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC). The PRB selects the U.S. Delegates and the members of the U.S. delegation, through which the PRB facilitates U.S. participation in the biennial SCAR meetings and the annual IASC meetings. The U.S. delegates to IASC and SCAR also serve as ex-officio members of the PRB to ensure communication and coordination.

The Board typically convenes two meetings a year, in the spring and fall. Board meetings are designed to provide an open forum to highlight important polar science issues. Agency officials are encouraged to participate, and efforts are made to engage a diverse cross-section of the polar community. PRB meetings have provided a valuable forum for fostering exchange of information and perspectives among a wide array of stakeholders in the polar science community. During their meetings, the Board discusses recent and current studies, ideas for possible future activities, current developments with SCAR and IASC, and briefings about the polar research activities of several federal agencies.

The Board has overseen the development and execution of numerous studies and workshop activities carried out by ad hoc committees. The Board’s role in design and oversight of studies is a key part of its work. The following are some recent examples of these types of activities and the reports are available on the National Academies Press website (http://www.nap.edu/):

  • Thriving on Our Changing Planet A Decadal Strategy for Earth Observation from Space (2018) – together with the Space Studies Board, Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate, Ocean Studies Board, Board on Earth Sciences and Resources, and the Water Science and Technology Board
  • Acquisition and Operation of Polar Icebreakers: Fulfilling the Nation’s Needs (2017) – together with the Transportation Research Board
  • Antarctic Sea Ice Variability in the Southern Ocean-Climate System: Proceedings of a Workshop (2017)
  • A Strategic Vision for NSF Investments in Antarctic and Southern Ocean Research (2015)

The PRB has also developed the “Arctic Matters” Public Engagement Initiative. Timed to coincide with the U.S. Chairmanship of the Arctic Council (2015-2017), the goal of the project was to expand public understanding of Arctic change and its potential impacts around the world. A suite of educational resources were developed including a 30 page booklet, a companion interactive website, and a classroom poster. Those resources have been widely distributed to thousands of people, at both national and international levels. In January 2016, the PRB held “Arctic Matters Day” a full-day, free public symposium, that attracted approximately 500 people. The day included “TED-like” keynote presentations, a series of panel discussions, and an array of interactive exhibits about Arctic science. We are continuing to distribute the Arctic Matters educational resources, and to explore other possible public engagement opportunities. Additional information can be found here: http://nas-sites.org/arctic/.

The Board’s overall mission is not to conduct research, but to focus and integrate information and thus give polar research more visibility and a broader impact on society, both in the United States and internationally. The Board will continue to facilitate U.S. participation in IASC and SCAR and seek ways to make these organizations valuable to U.S. interests. The Board will also continue to seek ways to encourage public engagement and educational opportunities that will help advance knowledge of the polar regions.

The PRB website (http://dels.nas.edu/prb/) contains information about the mission and objectives of the Polar Research Board, as well as information about all PRB activities and links to other resources.
